title: Man United beating Liverpool would be bigger upset than when Wigan beat City – Souness
text:
Souness played for Liverpool and cannot see them losing today (Picture: Getty)

Graeme Souness reckons Manchester United beating Liverpool would be one of the biggest upsets in recent history.

United will start as 4/1 underdogs with the bookies when league leaders Liverpool walk out Old Trafford hoping to continue their 100 per cent record in the Premier League this season.

Their opponents meanwhile could slip to 15th in the table by Tuesday morning if they lose at home and other results go against them.

Solskjaer and Klopp will face off at Old Trafford today (Picture: Getty)

Former Liverpool midfielder Souness cannot see them picking up a win against Liverpool.

‘If Manchester United beat Liverpool at Old Trafford today, it will be the biggest upset in top-flight football since Manchester City lost to Wigan in the 2013 FA Cup final,’ Souness wrote in his Sunday Times column.

‘I’m not saying that for the effect, I’m not saying it because I’m an ex-Liverpool player.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘I’m saying that because that’s what all the relevant indicators signify: the strength on paper of the respective squads; the fitness of key players (Paul Pogba out for United and maybe David de Gea too); the fact that Jurgen Klopp knows his best starting XI and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer clearly doesn’t; and recent form.’

United have managed just one win from their past seven for their opponents and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer finds himself under pressure to get a result and kick the side out of their recent malaise.

Reports in Italy this week even suggested that the club were quietly trying to agree a deal with ex-Juventus Max Allegri as a potential replacement but executive vice-chairman Ed Woodward has since come out in support of his manager.

‘Ole has also instilled the discipline back into an environment where we may have lacked it in recent years,’ Woodward said.

‘He is building a squad that respects the club’s history, in which players work hard and respect their team-mates. No-one is bigger than the club.’

Lukaku left United for Inter Milan over the summer (Picture: Getty)

But Souness believes that it is Woodward himself who is to blame for failing to give his manager the tools to succeed.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘If I was Ed Woodward I would have splashed the cash. United have had more misses than hits in their big-money signings in the past five years, but without proven performers at elite level it’s hard to see how they can scale the summit in the next five years,’ Souness added.

‘Failing to bring in a 20-goals-a-season striker when Romelu Lukaku departed in the summer sums up the flaw in their strategy.

‘Maybe Woodward doesn’t like the fact that selling clubs increasingly see United as a cash cow.

‘Gary Neville keeps telling me that United are going in a different direction from the one they took in the six years after Sir Alex Ferguson stood down.

‘I assume he means they are going to put their faith in a young manager and young players.

‘Good luck with that because I can’t see that direction taking them back to the top of the mountain.’
